title: The Coffeehouse
description: Live from the Coffeehouse at JKBoxed.com!

data.title: You Don't Know Me
data.description: My great friend Sugarchuck was in town and we were able to get together and record a few first takes. Here's the Cindy Walker/ Eddy Arnold masterpiece "You Don't Know Me:"                Yeah, we're working on the camera angles -- hang in there!

data.title: If I Only Had a Brain
data.description: We are still assembling "headliner" videos, but here is a solo version of "If I Only Had a Brain"

data.title: What a Wonderful World
data.description: My Sister-in-law, Rika, guests in the virtual coffeehouse today, singing one of my favorites, What a Wonderful World (Bob Thiele, George Douglas, George David Weiss).
data.composer: Bob Thiele, George Douglas, George David Weiss

data.title: Till There Was You
data.description: jk solo here on "'Till There Was You," from Meredith Wilson's The Music Man.

data.title: Do You Know What it Means?
data.description: Another from the fabled SugarChuck sessions: Do You Know What it Means (to Miss New Orleans)?

data.title: Stars Fell on Alabama
data.description: Time to take the new guitar out for a spin. In honor of her difficult humidity journey to Colorado: Stars Fell on Alabama by Frank Perkins and Mitchell Parish.

data.title: Don't Get Around Much Anymore
data.description: I'm the guest this week with a solo rendition of Duke Ellington's "Don't Get Around Much Anymore."

data.title: Paper Moon
data.description: A Harold Arlen and E.Y. Harburg tune that isn't in Wizard of Oz -- The famed SugarChuck sessions end with "(Say, It's Only a) Paper Moon."            Rumors abound of a second jk-SugarChuck session this summer -- we'll keep you informed...

data.title: Key to the Highway
data.description: Another round of the fabled SugarChuck sessions! SC and I dust off an old blues tune that we have been playing together for, well, forever.

data.title: Embraceable You
data.description: The SugarChuck Sessions continue with George and Ira Gershwin's "Embraceable You."

data.title: Route66
data.description: It's Lomas Avenue in Albuquerque, and a fun little shuffle.  SugarChuck joins me in the coffeehouse:

data.title: Wreck of the Old 97
data.description: My brothers, Dick and Howard, are in the coffeehouse. Enjoy our first release: Boxcar Willie's "Wreck of the Old 97."

data.title: All of Me
data.description: SugarChuck, a purple Telecaster, Seymour Simons's 1931 hit All of Me.

data.title: Home to Roost
data.description: My brother Howard plays one of his compositions: Home to Roost. Check out his website:  www.howardkranz.com

data.title: Great Art!
data.description: My brother, Howard Kranz, performs his composition, "Great Art."  Be sure to check out his website:  www.howardkranz.com

data.title: Partners
data.description: For a long time, my brothers have been doing this Jim Reeves song, Partners. Baby brother got to play along this time.  Sadly, this is the last of the Dick-Howard-John sessions. We get together every five years or so, we'll do some more next time.

data.title: I'm Confessin'
data.description: My nephew, RJ, is a very good drummer. He's more used to a full kit, but was over today and  good enough to humor me by playing my doumbek on Al Neiburg/Ellis Reynolds's I'm Confessin' (That I Love You).

data.title: Frim Fram Sauce
data.description: All my favorite players are on vacation, but I've dug up a golden oldie from last year. I played at my cousins' wedding reception:              Mazel Tov Mosh and Annabelle!   And special thanks to  rustyvision.com  for this video and buckets of good advice and technical direction. All the cool things you see around here are his, all the mistakes are mine.

data.title: Red Chevelle
data.description: A very special guest joins us this week. My cousin, Syd Phillips, whom I have exchanged email with but never met, sends in a video of his performing an original composition, Red Chevelle.

data.title: Johnny B Goode
data.description: Young Turk Ian Biley shakes things up at the coffeehouse with Chuck Berry's "Johnny B. Goode."

data.title: I've Got You Under My Skin
data.description: Something about a Telecaster® and a Cole Porter tune: "I've Got You Under My Skin."

data.title: Frog Giggin'
data.description: Cousin Syd was not certain that this met the standards of seriousness and decorum that we have established here at the virtual coffeehouse. I convinced him that it did.

data.title: Days of Wine and Roses
data.description: Music by Henry Mancini and lyrics by Johnny Mercer -- how you gonna beat that?

data.title: Casey's Last Ride
data.description: Only one thing better than putting on an old jacket and finding a $20 in the pocket: I found a SugarChuck video that I forgot I had. When we recorded it, I thought it an odd song for the coffeehouse. But I didn't know the coffeehouse well enough back then.  I’ve always liked simple country ballads, and this Kris Kristofferson song has meant a lot to me. Sugarchuck played this with me on my first album in 1981 (yeah, it came out on vinyl) and we reprise it here.

data.title: Key to the Highway (Ian)
data.description: After we finished  Johnny B Goode , Ian Biley joined me in a blues jam over "Key to the Hiughway."

data.title: Moonlight in Vermont
data.description: My Dad played piano and once told me that all the great players viewed this as their favorite tune: great changes, pretty melody. John Blackburn and Karl Suessdorf are not exactly household names, but in a just world they would be for writing "Moonlight in Vermont."

data.title: Since I Fell for You
data.description: The crimsonburst telecaster gets another workout on Buddy Johnson's "Since I Fell for You."              [Note to wardrobe: don't schedule the red shirt with the red guitar again. Maybe a maple colored shirt with a black pickguard or something...]

data.title: How High the Moon
data.description: How Red the Guitar! How Strong the coffee!               How long we gotta talk like this?

data.title: Take the A Train
data.description: My Berkeley Square brother, Kurt O, sends in a great guest video this week, Billy Strayhorn's Take the A Train

data.title: C'est Si Bon
data.description: We have a very special guest this week at the virtual coffeehouse. We caught up with 3/5 of The Hoagies playing at the very corporeal J.J.'s Corner Coffee House in Frederick Colorado and recorded a few great tunes. The second set opened with "C'est Si Bon," popularized both by Louis Armstrong and Eartha Kitt. The music was written in 1947 by Henri Betti, the French lyrics by André Hornez, and the English lyrics by Jerry Seelen               Visit The Hoagies website at  hoagiesjoint.com  and watch for more guest appearances.

data.title: Pennies from Heaven
data.description: What a great old Johnny Burke tune. My favorite version is from New Orleans trumpet master Leroy Jones but I snuck in a little homage to Louis Prima ("Sunshine and Ravioli").

data.title: I'll Never Say Never Again Again
data.description: The Hoagies are back with another great tune from their show at J.J.'s Corner in Frederick CO: Nat King Cole's I'll Never Say "Never Again" Again.

data.title: Only Time
data.description: Happy Thanksgiving! I'm thankful for some great friends who are great players. Now another has dropped by the virtual coffeehouse.  This is from Test of Time's CD release party -- here's the title cut: "Only Time"

data.title: You've Been Away
data.description: Back to the Test of Time CD Release party. My friend, Wes, is joined by his grandson for "You've Been Away."

data.title: Killer Joe
data.description: Flat Out is in the coffeehouse with Benny Golson's "Killer Joe."

data.title: Stardust
data.description: The Hoagies do their namesake proud: Hoagy Carmichael's beautiful "Stardust."

data.title: Summertime
data.description: The lads from Flat Out are back in the coffeehouse with George Gershwin's "Summertime."

data.title: Alfie
data.description: I used to sing this song to my friends' cat. Now I understand Alfie has gone to kitty heaven after 17 years.   Neither my feline friend nor I ever made it past the first eight bars, so I had to learn this tune for the coffeehouse's first special dedication.  It's an unusual and pretty song from Burt Bacharach and Hal David in 1966.

data.title: Blues by Five
data.description: Flat Out Jazz with Hank Garland's classic, Blues by Five.

data.title: It Could Happen to You
data.description: In a just world, Greg Keelor and Jim Cuddy (you bet I had to look that up) wold be household names for this wonderful tune.

data.title: Misty
data.description: I'm my own guest this week. I found some old video laying around that my friend Byurhan had shot with his new camera. He bought it when he was visiting from Ireland 2003-4, sometime around then. Here's Errol Garner's Misty:              It is "our song" and it is fun to see the old house and my lovely bride's clapping with two hands. Can't say I remember the shirt -- but it goes with the Cinema Verite, n'est ce pas?

data.title: La Vie En Rose
data.description: Edith Piaf's classic, La Vie En Rose. I started using the "Kindhearted Woman" intro and thought if I was going to play it as a blues, I better get out the telecaster.

data.title: If I Ruled the World
data.description: Here's one for you Angel fans. "If I Ruled the World" by Leslie Bricusse and Cyril Ornadel,

data.title: All the Way
data.description: Keep them Sammy Cahn tunes coming! Sammy Cahn and Jimmie Van Huesen's "All the Way."

data.title: Corina, Corina
data.description: I knew we needed some new guest performances around here and the magical mystical Internet delivers. My Cousin Syd in the great state of Tennessee sends this great version of Corina, Corina.              I always liked hearing Taj Mahal do this. Syd discovered it on a Steppenwolf Live album when he was a lad. Great tune -- enjoy!

data.title: A Nightingale Sang in Berkeley Square
data.description: Gotta get Brooke into the coffeehouse to sing it, but in the meantime...

data.title: All the Things You Are
data.description: Mister Jerome Kern

data.title: Over the Rainbow
data.description: Harold Arlen's bewitching melody. (And those are E Y Harbirg's lyrics running in your mind.)

data.title: Jeepers Creepers
data.description: A beloved relative was over and picked up my Johnny Mercer book, It is truly amazing how many incredible songs he enlyriced.

data.title: Belle Isle Streetcar Line
data.description: (Bumped for Centenary)   A very special guest today: my Dad, Walter H Kranz (1913-1994).              I had just purchased an 8mm camcorder and caught my Dad playing the song he wrote for my Mom when they first dated in Oklahoma City.

data.title: Goody Goody
data.description: I got to play with  my brothers  last year, shortly after the virtual coffeehouse opened.  I now welcome my lovely and talented sister, Diane, with Johnny Mercer's "Goody Goody."

data.title: Alleghany Moon
data.description: My sister Diane, and Alleghany Moon by Al Hoffman and Dick Manning (1956).

data.title: This Nearly Was Mine
data.description: Rodgers and Hammerstein (South Pacific, 1949). Too sad to sing, so here's an instrumental:

data.title: Guilty
data.description: We are joined by my great friend Mike on Randy Newman's "Guilty"

data.title: Damn Your Eyes
data.description: Our friend Mike is back in the coffeehouse as we take on "Damn Your Eyes" as recorded by Ms. Etta James.

data.title: Angel from Montgomery
data.description: The Mike & jk sessions come to a sad but powerful close today with John Prine's "Angel from Montgomery"            Reaction has been great, we'll have to drag those two back.

data.title: Girl from Ipanema
data.description: The standard of standards: Antonio Carlos Jobim's "Girl from Ipanema."      UPDATE: Bumped for  The 50th Anniversary  (Original date Jun 24, 2010)

data.title: Sunny Side of the Street
data.description: Longtime fave. Jimmy McHugh and Dorothy Fields.

data.title: Rusty Metal Box
data.description: Cousin Syd sends a guest video of his friends at the historic Blue Bird Cafe in Nashville.  Tom Manning is singing his original composition, Rusty Metal Box. Playing guitar across from him is Martin Young.

data.title: Then You Can Tell Me Goodbye
data.description: What a great song. I heard a terrible elevator-music version in a Chinese restaurant and the tune stuck in my head. (You should have heard their version of "Whiter Shade of Pale.")  The coffeehouse muse ran down the tune for me. It was written by John D. Loudermilk.

data.title: Pourin'
data.description: Cousin Syd  sent in some superb guest videos from the historic Blue Bird Cafe in Nashville.  Here are his friends Tom Manning, Age McCann and Susan Marshall. The song is called "Pourin'"

data.title: It Takes a Lot to Laugh
data.description: It Takes a Lot to Laugh, It Takes a Train to Cry.  I always liked this Bob Dylan tune. And we needed a little more blues around here...

data.title: Misty
data.description: Erroll Garner's classic -- our song.

data.title: The Deal
data.description: Can't have a coffeehouse with no Dead tunes, it's in the rules. This is one of my favorites.

data.title: Polka Dots and Moonbeams
data.description: Watching the Tour de France, and the "King of the Mountains" is awarded a Polka Dot jersey by two attractive young French women in Polka Dot dresses.  Made me think of this great Jimmy Van Huesen-Johnny Burke song:

data.title: Ghost Riders in the Sky
data.description: That's my brother Dick, sister Diane, and great-nephews Brian (bass) and Nathan (keys). Yippie-I-Ay!

data.title: Belle Isle Streetcar Line
data.description: Words and music Walter H. Kranz.  (his version) . Performing three days after his Centenary: sons Dick and John, [Only] Daughter [Princess] Diane, Great-Grandchildren Brian and Nathan.

data.title: Sabor a Mi
data.description: Love this tune! Original words and music by Alvaro Carrillo. English lyrics by Mel Mitchell.       Thanks to my lovely Mother-in-law for the charts!
data.composer: Alvaro Carrillo. English lyrics by Mel Mitchell

data.title: Route 66
data.description: I finally get a chance to play with my friend Kirk!  I was too busy missing changes and forgetting the tunes that I'd picked to run the cameras well, but it was fun. Head on down to Lomas Avenue with us:      And visit his  excellent wine store  in Denver.

data.title: Skylark
data.description: One more from the  City Wine  Sessions:

data.title: All of Me
data.description: Sadly the last of the City Wine Sessions with Kirk: Seymour Simon's 1931 hit!

data.title: Everything Happens to Me
data.description: Love this Tom Adair & Matt Dennis  tune. A bit of Googling shows a Johnny Mercer/Hoagy Carmichael song by the same name. I've got to go hunting for that -- I've never heard it.

data.title: I'm in the Mood for Love
data.description: Jimmy McHugh and Dorothy Fields's "I'm in the Mood for Love" from 1935.

data.title: Witchcraft
data.description: Happy Halloween from Live at the Coffehouse dot Com!

data.title: Prenup
data.description: Our friend Tom Manning played at the Historic Blue Bird in Nashville last night and Cousin Syd got the video.   It's called, "Prenup." and it's written by Manning and Harry W. Moodie. Martin Young is the awesome guitar player backing him up.

data.title: Bewitched, Bothered and Bewildered
data.description: The Halloween medley continues (I think we can milk this for this week and next...)  Rodgers and Hart's Bewitched, Bothered and Bewildered:

data.title: That Old Black Magic
data.description: How can you not close out the Halloween medly with Johnny Mercer's "That Old Black Magic?"

data.title: Wind Beneath my Wings
data.description: All our special guests are special at liveatthecoffeehouse.com. But today's is what we in the virtual coffeehouse business call "a get."  Cousin Syd caught  Larry Henley  at the Blue Bird in Nashville, performing a beautiful version of his beautiful song "Wind Beneath my Wings." (Did I mention it was a #1 Billboart Hit?) Mr. Henly graciously agreed to let us post it.

data.title: Kindhearted Woman Blues
data.description: By the one and only Robert Johnson.

data.title: Freight Train
data.description: The 60's folk revival brought this song back, but most did not credit Elizabeth Cotten who wrote it.

data.title: Let it Snow! Let it Snow! Let it Snow!
data.description: jk keeps them Sammy Cahn tunes coming -- in a Santa Hat!

data.title: My Funny Valentine
data.description: My mother was born on Valentine's Day. And she always did a great job pretending to like my music. So this one's for her:       My Funny Valentine  from  liveatthecoffeehouse  on  Vimeo .  Rodgers & Hart meet the new mandolin.  [Originally posted Feb 8, 2011]

data.title: Stars Fell on Alabama
data.description: jk solo on this great Frank Perkins -Mitchell Parish tune.

data.title: How High the Moon
data.description: Nancy Hamilton (lyrics) and Morgan Lewis (music) wrote this great tune, but I will always associate it with the immortal Les Paul. And I just bought a this new Les Paul guitar...

data.title: Heaven Please
data.description: By the great Percy Mayfield. I learned this "on the street" and may not have all the right lyrics. But it's a great tune for a blue guitar.

data.title: Misty (Instrumental)
data.description: Errol Garner, ©1954. But, more importantly, "Our Song."

data.title: Jingle Bell Rock
data.description: Jingle Bell Rock was written by Joseph Carleton Beal and James Ross Boothe, but the song owes its popularity to Hank Garland's guitar work. Just sayin'  Now I know how Santa feels, because I recorded this on Christmas Eve and rushed to get it out to the good little boys and girls (but you can listen to...)

data.title: Prelude to a Kiss
data.description: Duke!

data.title: Don't Fence Me In
data.description: I get accused of too many slow, rubato ballads but this really is a pretty melody -- it deserves a little air.

data.title: Do Nuthin' 'Till you Hear from Me
data.description: His Dukeness again.

data.title: That Mesmerizing Mendellsohn Tune
data.description: As played on the Titanic, 100 years ago! Irving Berlin c1909      Honey, listen to that dreamy tune they're playin'  Won't you tell me how on earth you keep from swayin'?  Umm! Umm! Oh, that Mendelssohn Spring Song tune  If you ever loved me show me now or never  Lord, I wish they'd play that music on forever  Umm! Umm! Oh, that Mendelssohn tune  My honey.    Love me to that ever lovin' Spring Song melody  Please me, honey, squeeze me to that Mendelssohn strain  Kiss me like you would your mother  One good kiss deserves another  That's the only music that was ever meant for me  That tantalizin', hypnotizin', mesmerizin' Mendelssohn tune.

data.title: This Time the Dream's on Me
data.description: Johnny Mercer and Harol Arlen -- can't go wrong.

data.title: Tangerine
data.description: Last time I did a Johnny Mercer song, I got several compliments -- plus one for the hat. Here's another great Johnny Mercer song. In the hat.

data.title: Kindhearted Woman Blues
data.description: Travelled to an undisclosed location to record this great Robert Johnson tune with my friend Sugarchuck.

data.title: Stardust
data.description: We'll be back to the Sugarchuck sessions next week. But I had a bunch of new gear to try out. Who better than Hoagy Carmichael?

data.title: Come Together
data.description: I NEVER get asked to sing backup -- what fun to do so with Mollie Dangerbucket and Sugarchuck.

data.title: Fruits of My Labor
data.description: Mollie & Sugarchuck provide a beautiful take on this song by Lucinda Williams.

data.title: At Last
data.description: At Last! The coffeehouse finally features a Mack Gordon and Harry Warren  tune!

data.title: It Could Happen to You
data.description: Sadly, the last of the Sugarchuck Sessions: music by Jimmy Van Heusen and lyrics by Johnny Burke (c)1944
data.composer: Jimmy Van Heusen and lyrics by Johnny Burke

data.title: Let it Snow! Let it Snow! Let it Snow!
data.description: Hat. Uke. Sammy Cahn tune...

data.title: Makin' Whoopie
data.description: A few friends join me for a Fats Waller tune

data.title: Bei Mir Bist du Schön
data.description: My sister, Diane, and my great-nephew, Brian, come to the coffeehouse to reprise "Bei Mir Bist du Schoen" by Jacob Jacobs and Sholom Secunda. The three of us did this at a memorial for my brother-in-law, Bob.

data.title: Rhythm Changes: I've Got Rhythm / Flintstones
data.description: George & Ira Gershwin   (Flintstones Theme by William Hanna and Joseph Barbera)
data.composer: George & Ira Gershwin   (Flintstones Theme by William Hanna and Joseph Barbera)

data.title: Straighten Up and Fly Right
data.description: Nat King Cole & Irving Mills ©1943

data.title: Blue Christmas
data.composer: Billy Hayes and Jay W. Johnson

data.title: If I Were a Bell
data.description: Take the new, green guitar out for a spin...

data.title: Kind Hearted Woman
data.description: We've had requests before, but this was the first request with a delicate guitar paring. Our sommelier wanted to hear "Kind Hearted Woman" on "the surf green guitar/"  Voila! Ooh-eh the surf-verte guitare...

data.title: That's Amore
data.composer: Harry Warren (born Salvatore Antonio Guaragna) and lyrics Jack Brooks

data.title: That's How Strong my Love is
Bein' Green
data.description: I struggled to find the right guitar for this tune. I wanted a more acoustic tone for the open/midrange chords without losing the low end. I hope I made the right choice.

data.title: My Baby Just Cares for Me
data.composer: Walter Donaldson with lyrics by Gus Kahn

data.title: When Your Lover Has Gone
data.description: I am pleased to have a very special guest this week: my sister, Diane. This one goes out to her dear husband and my dear friend, Bob, on the anniversary of his birth. Miss you, man.       ©1931 Einar Aaron Swan

data.title: Azure Te
data.description: Happy Bastille Day!

data.title: Summertime / Azure Te
data.description: Summer Te!        Sugar Chuck  opened the Coffeehouse with me -- it was great to have him in town. He knew"Summertime" by Gershwin -- I knew Azure Te (Don Wolf, Bill Davis). Mashups being all the rage . . .
data.composer: Summertime by Gershwin, Azure Te by Don Wolf, Bill Davis

data.title: A Nightingale Sang in Berkeley Square
data.description: You know what they say . . . "Once you go four -- you'll never want more!" The tenor is back for my favorite tune.

data.title: What a Wonderful World
data.description: I played this for the wedding of my lovely niece, Kyler to newly-minted nephew, Jaimie. But it was drier to reprise it in the Coffeehouse Studios... #kyandjamietietheknot.
data.composer: Bob Thiele and George David Weiss

data.title: Lullaby of Birdland
data.composer: George Shearing and George David Weiss

data.title: Angel
data.description: A special request from coffeehouse friend Sugarchuck. Jazz-schmazz, let's hear some Hendrix!

data.title: Blue Eyes Crying in the Rain
data.description: My lovely and talented sister, Diane, lets me join on "Blue Eyes Crying in the Rain," just in time for Willie Nelson's Birthday and her anniversary.

data.title: Scotch and Soda
data.description: Dave Guard of the Kingston Trio gets the writing credit, but its provenance is a bit more  complicated .

data.title: Do you Know what it Means?
Misty
data.description: "OurSong!"

data.title: Ain't Misbehavin'
data.composer: Fats Waller, Harry Brooks, and Andy Razaf

data.title: You Dont Know Me
data.description: Eddy Arnold & Cindy Walker

data.title: Red River Valley
data.description: Riza lends me her banjolele for this traditional tune.

data.title: Always
data.description: I confess I did not know about Nick Lucas until I found myself the proud owner of a "Nick Lucas Model" guitar. Researching the great cowboy singer, I was struck that his repertoire closely match my Father's favorite songs -- even including one I thought Dad had written. I heard Dad sing this 100 times; here 'tis in Nick Lucas style (though I cannot pull off the operatic tenor voice).

data.title: Unforgettable/What a Wonderful World
data.description: Unforgettable -- Irving Gordon ©1951 What a Wonderful World -- Bob Thiele and George David Weiss. ©1967

data.title: Thinking Out Loud
data.description: My friend Tyler sang this at his mother's wedding and killed it. I had the misfortune to follow him.  In spite of that brutal upstaging, I was quite taken with the tune.

data.title: La Vie en Rose Blues
data.description: In case last years's shuffle version  was not odd enough, I added some blues licks.

data.title: Here, There and Everywhere
data.description: Lennon-McCartney

data.title: I Will
data.description: Lennon-McCartney

data.title: Where the Columbines Grow
data.description: The Colorado State Song on its Centenary.   For an interesting look at the composer and the tune, Rob Natelson has an  interesting paper.

data.title: What Now My Love?
data.description: Gilbert Bécaud and lyricist Pierre Delanoë. (English lyrics Carl Sigman).
data.composer: Gilbert Bécaud and lyricist Pierre Delanoë

data.title: Three Coins in the Fountain
data.description: Keep them Sammy Cahn tunes coming! ©1954

data.title: Smile
data.composer: Charlie Chaplin Lyrics John Turner & Geoffrey Parsons

data.title: Like Someone in Love
data.description: Only one camera and severe performance flaws -- y'all should get a discount on this one. But I did want to show the new Epiphone Gold Top.

data.title: Dahil Sa Iyo
data.description: In honor of the greatest Mother-in-law and Father-in-law of all time.

data.title: Ain't Misbehavin'
data.description: Was that a good time or what? Kurt O is back in the LiveAtTheCoffehouse.com "A" Studios.

data.title: Don't Get Around Much Anymore
data.description: The Kurt O sessions continue!

data.title: Angel Eyes
data.description: The Kurt O sessions, sadly, come to a close today, though there was speculation for another.
data.composer: Matt Dennis, lyrics by Earl Brent

data.title: Teddy and Tat
data.description: Written for my sister, Diane by my Aunt Mary. The real "Teddy and Tat" have a cameo at the end.

data.title: Indian Summer
data.description: My lovely and talented sister, Diane, sings a tune she heard while out with my lovely and talented brother, Dick.

data.title: What Are You Doing New Year's Eve?
data.description: Wishing y'all a prosperous and generally awesome 2017!

data.title: All in the Game
data.description: "The only No. 1 pop single to have been co-written by a U.S. Vice President or winner of the Nobel Peace Prize."
data.composer: Music Charles Gates Dawes, lyrics Carl Sigman

data.title: Tears
data.description: Something from my new internet friend, Steve. I encourage you to check out more of his stuff at  Fused Improv

data.title: I'm an Old Cowhand from the Rio Grande
data.description: Johnny Mercer!

data.title: You Never Can Tell
data.description: Requiescat in pace, Mister Berry.

data.title: Got You on my Mind
data.description: Happy Birthday, Eric Clapton! From me and my lovely and talented sister, Diane.

data.title: Ths Time the Dream's on Me
O Canada!
data.description: From  Wikipedia : The song was originally commissioned by Lieutenant Governor of Quebec Théodore Robitaille for the 1880 Saint-Jean-Baptiste Day ceremony; Calixa Lavallée composed the music, after which, words were written by the poet and judge Sir Adolphe-Basile Routhier. The lyrics were originally in French; an English version was created in 1906. Robert Stanley Weir wrote in 1908 another English version, which is the official and most popular version, one that is not a literal translation of the French. Weir's lyrics have been revised twice, taking their present form in 1980, but the French lyrics remain unaltered. "O Canada" had served as a de facto national anthem since 1939, officially becoming Canada's national anthem in 1980 when the Act of Parliament making it so received royal assent and became effective on July 1 as part of that year's Dominion Day (now known as Canada Day) celebrations.

data.title: Who Can I Turn To?
data.description: Two life lessons from today's selection: 1. Never underestimate the healing power of a sad but pretty song. 2. Don't get too worked up over grammar.

data.title: Stars Fell on Alabama
data.description: My sister, Diane, and brother, Dick, join me for a Father's Day tribute to my Alabama-born father. Next year, we'll find a way to get Howard in.

data.title: Wave
data.description: One more Father's Day tribute -- as I was blessed with two. My Father-in-law was a big fan of Jobim.

data.title: City of Stars
data.description: At last -- my lovely bride joins me in the Coffeehouse for a duet!
data.composer: Justin Hurwitz, Lyrics by Benj Pasek & Justin Paul

data.title: Wichita Lineman
data.description: Special guest Erik Guthrie joins me in the Coffeehouse for a homage to the most awesome Glen Campbell.

data.title: In the Cool, Cool, Cool of the Evening
You Belong to Me
data.description: My lovely bride joins me in the Coffeehouse 'A' studio!
data.composer: Pee Wee King, Chilton Price and Redd Stewart

data.title: He Fell for the Magic of 3/4 Time
data.description: This is my first original tune in more than 25 years. Thanks to some great old friends -- and new -- who got together to help me do it. John Kranz ©2017

data.title: I Want a Hippopotamus for Christmas
data.description: Pachyderms and yuletide greetings from all your friends at Live at the Coffeehouse!

data.title: Misty (Tenor Version)
data.description: The Tenorcaster! And "Our Song."

data.title: Danny Boy
data.description: I reserve license to reprise this for St. Patricks Day on the green electric mandolin. But it has a warmth on the tenor:      Traditional

data.title: Comes Love (Dobro)
data.description: I've had a great "embarrasment of riches" problem in that a few of my friends were very good slide players. This provided a convenient excuse to avoid umm, learning, and practice, and things like that.  But the "Sun Moon and Stars" Dobro has taken my heart, and I am having fun being an absolute beginner:
data.composer: Sam H. Stept, lyrics by Lew Brown and Charles Tobias

data.title: All in the Game
data.description: I have a soft spot for Vice President Charles Gates Dawes. He shouted "Hell and Maria!" at a congressional hearing, was a banker, philanthropist, Quartermaster General in WWI, Nobel laureate... And he wrote this tune as an instrumental in 1912. Four decades later, they added lyrics and sent it to #1:
data.composer: Charles G. Dawes melody(1911). Carl Sigman, lyrics

data.title: See You in my Dreams
data.description: I learned Django's Intro. Then my inner troubadour couldn't not do at least a chorus. Short, sweet, no singin' -- just what the focus groups say y'all want.
